questions.text: All of the following are ionising radiation except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Radio waves Radio waves are non ionising radiation

Highyeild:

Radiation is classified as being either non-ionizing or ionizing. Non-ionizing radiation is longer wavelength/lower frequency lower energy. While ionizing radiation is short wavelength/high frequency higher energy. Ionizing Radiation has sufficient energy to produce ions in matter at the molecular level.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Ƴ rays Option: B. α rays Option: D. X rays all are ionising radiation

Extraedge:

Any radiation capable of making the particle charged or ionised. Any radiation which is not capable of making the particle charged or ionised. Examples X rays Ƴ rays α rays β rays Cosmic rays Examples: Visible light UV rays IR rays Microwaves Radio waves Higher frequency and energy Lower frequency and energy. lonisation: Energy associated with radiation can be transferred to matter. This transfer of energy can remove electrons from the orbit of atoms leading to the formation of ions. E=hv Where E is the energy, h is Plank's constant and v is the frequency of the radiation. Therefore, as the frequency increases, energy increases/ the capability of removing the electrons increases/ ionising power increases Ƴ RAYS X RAYS MRI PET Radiography USG Bone scan CT scan Thermography Thyroid scan Mammography DTPA Angiography Thallium scan MCU, RGU Tc based scans HSG, IVP DEXA

questions.text: Match the following about X-ray tube: Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a-2, b-4, c-1, d-3

Highyeild:

An X-ray tube is a vacuum tube that converts electrical input power into X-rays The availability of this controllable source of X-rays created the field of radiography, the imaging of partly opaque objects with penetrating radiation. In contrast to other sources of ionizing radiation, X-rays are only produced as long as the X-ray tube is energized

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Parts of X ray tube: 1. Glass envelope: Made of pyrex glass Provides a protected and vaccumated environment to the tube Cathode: Negatively charged Filament , the most important part, is made of tungsten. It emits electrons on passing electricity, called THERMOIONIC EMISSION. Thorium is added to increase the stability of filament. Anode: Positively charged. Made of copper . Target (at the centre of anode plate)- made of tungsten Target window: To allow x rays to come out Thinning of glass envelope In mammography, it is made of Beryllium Filter: Blocks low energy radiation Made of Aluminium Collimator: It is a beam restricting device. Reduces scatter radiation Made of lead

Extraedge:

The cathode, anode, rotor apparatus, and the other associated structures are collectively called the X-ray tube insert. They are all contained in a glass or metal enclosure and sealed under a high vacuum. This enclosure is known as the envelope. X-ray photons emitted from the focal spot scatter in all directions

questions.text: Interaction between a low energy incident photon and the inner shell electron is known as?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Photoelectric effect Photoelectric effect is an interaction between low energy x-ray beam and the inner shell electron .

Highyeild:

Inner shell electron is ejected, the outer electron goes onto inner orbit to occupy the space and the extra energy is ejected due to photoelectric effect . High energy electrons are not capable of this due to random scattering from outer shell known as Compton effect , which can lead to distortion of image. The goal must be to maximise photoelectric effect and minimise Compton effect.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A: Compton effect High energy electrons are not capable of this due to random scattering from outer shell known as Compton effect, which can lead to distortion of image. Option C: Annihilation radiation is a term used in gamma spectroscopy to describe the photon radiation produced when a particle and its antiparticle collide and annihilate. In this process, both particles are destroyed, and their combined mass is converted into energy.

Extraedge:

questions.text: Bragg peak effect is produced by?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Proton Bragg peak effect is pronounced in proton. The curve plots the energy loss of ionising radiation during its travel through matter.

Highyeild:

The proton gradually loses its speed as it interacts with human tissue. The absorbed dose increases very gradually with greater depth and lower speed, suddenly rising to a peak when it is ultimately stopped , which is known as the Bragg peak. The proton can be directed so that the Bragg peak occurs exactly within the tumour site. Proton therapy allows to target tumours inside the body, precisely localise the radiation dosage and sparing the healthy cells .

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Electron Option: B. Neutron Option: C. X ray They do not show Bragg peak effect

Extraedge:

The Bragg peak is a pronounced peak on the Bragg curve which plots the energy loss of ionizing radiation during its travel through matter. For protons, α-rays, and other ion rays, the peak occurs immediately before the particles come to rest. It is named after William Henry Bragg, who discovered it in 1903.

questions.text: Read the following statements and choose the correct option: X rays are extranuclear in origin Y rays are intranuclear in origin
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both 1 and 2 are true X rays are extranuclear in origin and Ƴ rays are intranuclear in origin

Highyeild:

Both X rays and Ƴ rays are ionising radiation. Both the rays do not differ except in their source of production.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Gamma rays are produced intranuclearly and X rays are produced extra-nuclearly (mechanically).

Extraedge:

X-rays are photons emitted from the electron shells surrounding the atomic nucleus or during the slowing down of electrons or other charged particles. The term γ -rays is usually applied to radiation originating from the atomic nucleus, and from particle annihilation.

Solution:

α rays α rays have highest ionisation potential

Highyeild:

Rays with highest ionisation potential- α rays Rays with highest mass - α rays Rays with highest biological effect - α rays Rays with linear energy transfer- α rays Rays with most damaging power - α rays Rays with highest penetrating power- Ƴ rays

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Decreasing order of ionisation power : α>neutron>β>γ So, α particles has the maximum ionisation power.

Extraedge:

Ionization potential is three potential differences corresponding to the energy in electron volts that is just sufficient to ionize a gas molecule or to remove an electron completely from the atom. The energy equivalent to ionization potential is called ionization energy and measured in electron volt.

questions.text: The amount of X-rays/ Ƴ-rays that liberate a charge of 2.58 x 10-4C/kg of air, under standard temperature and pressure is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Roentgen Roentgen, u nit of X-radiation or gamma radiation, th e amount that will produce, under normal conditions of pressure, temperature, and humidity, in 1 kg (2.2 lbs) of air, an amount of positive or negative ionization equal to 2.58 × 10 −4 coulomb. It is named for the German physicist Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen.

Highyeild:

The roentgen (R) unit refers to the amount of ionization present in the air. One roentgen of gamma- or x-ray exposure produces approximately 1 rad (0.01 gray) tissue dose

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Rad- An absorbed dose of 1 rad means that 1 gram of material absorbed 100 ergs of energy (a small but measurable amount) as a result of exposure to radiation Option: C. Rem- The roentgen equivalent man (rem) is a CGS unit of equivalent dose, effective dose, and committed dose, which are dose measures used to estimate potential health effects of low levels of ionizing radiation on the human body. Option: D. Sievert-The international system (SI) unit for dose equivalent equal to 1 Joule/kilogram. 1 sievert = 100 rem.

questions.text: The effective dose of Chest Xray PA view is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

0.02mSv

Highyeild:

Effective Dose Effective dose is calculated for the whole body. It is the addition of equivalent doses to all organs, each adjusted to account for the sensitivity of the organ to radiation. Effective dose is expressed in millisieverts (mSv). Equivalent Dose Equivalent dose is calculated for individual organs. It is based on the absorbed dose to an organ, adjusted to account for the effectiveness of the type of radiation. Equivalent dose is expressed in millisieverts (mSv) to an organ.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. 0.3mSv ; Pelvis AP CT Option: B. 0.15mSv; Thoracic spine CT Option: D. 2mSv;Head CT

questions.text: Which of the following is not a deterministic effect of radiation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Teratogenicity Teratogenicity is not a deterministic effect of radiation. It is included in stochastic effect.

Highyeild:

Stochastic effects occur by chance and can be compared to deterministic effects which result in a direct effect. Cancer induction and radiation induced hereditary effects are the two main examples of stochastic effects.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A Infertility Option: B Alopecia Option: D Cataract Option: A,B,D are deterministic effects of radiation.

Extraedge:

Deterministic effect: Stochastic effect: Radiation effects at high doses Dose-independent effects Cell death e.g. erythema Carcinogenesis and genetic mutation Probability increases when dose is increased Probability increases when dose is increased

Solution:

3 months

Highyeild:

TLD (Thermo luminescent dorsi meter) is used to monitor radiation dose in India, for radiation workers. It is made up of Lithium fluoride or dysprosium It is checked every 3 months.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A,C,D are incorrect

Extraedge:

A thermoluminescent dosimeter , or TLD , is a type of radiation dosimeter, consisting of a piece of a thermoluminescent crystalline material inside a radiolucent package. When a thermoluminescent crystal is exposed to ionizing radiation, it absorbs and traps some of the energy of the radiation in its crystal lattice. When heated, the crystal releases the trapped energy in the form of visible light, the intensity of which is proportional to the intensity of the ionizing radiation the crystal was exposed to.

questions.text: The maximum radiation limit for a pregnant patient is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

5mSv/term The principle that has to be followed while exposing any patient/worker to radiation is ALARA principle.

Highyeild:

ALARA- As Low As Reasonably Achievable. CATEGORY DOSE LIMIT (mSv) Patient 50mSv/yr Occupational worker 100mSv/5yr Pregnant patient 5mSv/term Pregnant occupational worker 2mSv/declared term General public 1mSv/yr

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. 10mSv/term Option: C. 1mSv/term -For general public Option: D. 2mSv/term-For pregnant occupational worker

Extraedge:

The guiding principle of radiation safety is “ ALARA”. ALARA stands for “ as low as reasonably achievable” . ALARA means avoiding exposure to radiation that does not have a direct benefit to you, even if the dose is small.

questions.text: A 16 year old boy came with complain of Runny nose, Pain over cheeks & mild fever. He has multiple episode of same in last 10 years. Provisional. Diagnosis of chronic sinusitis & was made. Which view is used to virtualize paranasal sinuses?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Water's view Syn. Occipitomental view A radiographic view, where an X- ray beam is angled at 45° to the orbit meatal line Rays pass from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate Commonly used to get a better view of the maxillary sinuses

Highyeild:

Water's view (also known as the occipito-mental view) helps to get a better view of the maxillary sinuses by using an X-ray beam angled at 45° to the orbito-meatal line.It is a method of imaging that shows the paranasal sinuses.. (PNS) along with surrounding soft tissues.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Towne's view -visualizes the petrous part of the pyramids , the dorsum sellae Option: D. Sub mento vertical view - provides excellent visualization of the larynx without the necessity of extraneous contrast agents.

Extraedge:

Waters' view (also known as the occipitomental view) is a radiographic view of the skull. It is commonly used to get a better view of the maxillary sinuses . An x-ray beam is angled at 45° to the orbitomeatal line. The rays pass from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate.

questions.text: When should an Invertogram be performed in a newborn:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

After 6 hours Invertogram: A coin/metal piece is placed over the expected anus and the baby is turned upside down (for a minimum 3 minutes)

Highyeild:

Distance of gas bubble in rectum from the metal piece is noted: >2 cm: denotes high type < 2 cm: denotes low type

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: A,B,C are incorrect

Extraedge:

An invertogram may be used to investigate the extent of the defect in anal or rectal atresia. The anus is marked with a radiopaque marker, and the baby inverted. A lateral radiograph is taken. The air in the rectum will rise to the highest point, giving an indication of the extent of the atresia.

questions.text: Chiari II malformation diagnosed in a 2 year old child . After repair of associated lumbosacral myelomeningocele patient was diagnosed with hydrocele.First sign of hydrocephalus in children is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sutural diastasis Suture diastasis, the first and most important sign in small children, may be the only sign of raised pressure. Sellar erosion may occur but is a late sign and implies long standing chronic pressure.

Highyeild:

In children under 10, Sellar erosion without suture diastasis is likely to be due to a local erosive lesion rather than raised pressure. Above this age sellar changes are more likely to be due to raised pressure Sequence: Coronal > Sagittal >Lambdoid> Squamosal suture

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A,B,D are not the early signs seen in hydrocephalus in children

Extraedge:

Hydrocephalus denotes an increase in the volume of CSF, causing the distension of cerebral ventricles (ventriculomegaly) due to insufficient passage of the CSF from its point of production in the ventricles into the systemic circulation

questions.text: In fracture of nose, which view X-ray taken:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lateral view Lateral view of nasal bones (both right & left): Fracture line and depression or elevation of the fractured segment is seen Lower part of nasal bone (best viewed here) is thin and fractured more frequently

Highyeild:

Best view to evaluate trauma to face, Nasal fracture Occlusal view of nasal bone: Both side of nasal pyramid are seen Fracture line and l ateral displacement of the nasal pyramid is clearly seen Water's view: Gives end on view of nasal arch Fracture of right and left nasal bones and their lateral displacement can be seen

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Water view - used to see maxillary sinuses Option: B. Caldwell's view - Caldwell's view pe rforms well in assessing frontal and ethmoidal sinus opacification, as well as nasal septum deviation. Option D. Occlusal anterior view: This view isn't typically used for nasal fractures. It's often used in dental X-rays to visualize the upper and lower teeth in a bite position.

Extraedge:

The Waters view, or occipitomental view, is considered the best projection for evaluating maxillary sinuses, while the Caldwell view , or occipitofrontal view , is used primarily for the frontal and ethmoid sinuses. Sensitivity, however, is relatively low for all sinuses (25-41%) except for maxillary sinusitis (80% )

questions.text: Lemon sign&"Banana sign" are seen in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Spina bifida Spina bifida on USG

Highyeild:

Lemon sign: Relates to the abnormal shape of the head (In the second trimester, fetuses with open spina bifida tend to have a disproportionately small BPD for the gestational age) Banana sign: Related to herniation of the cerebellar vermis t hrough the banana-shaped foramen magnum

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Down syndrome - most common ultrasound findings in Down syndrome In the second trimester, the most commonly assessed soft markers include echogenic intracardiac foci, pyelectasis, short femur length, choroid plexus cysts, echogenic bowel, thickened nuchal skin fold, and ventriculomegaly. Option: C. Turner syndrome- radiological features of Turner syndrome Radiographic features cystic hygroma: may appear septated; one of the most typical features of Turner syndrome. increased nuchal thickness. increased nuchal translucency. coarctation of the aorta: 15-20% bicuspid aortic valve (BAV) omphalocele. horseshoe kidney / pelvic kidney. mild IUGR. Option: D. Periventricular leukomalacia - CT findings of end-stage PVL are irregular enlargement of the body and trigone of lateral ventricles; decreased white matter, which is conspicuous in the trigone but also in the centrum semiovale in severe cases; and deep sulci abutting the white matter due to loss of white matter.

Extraedge:

Spina bifida A birth defect in which a developing baby's spinal cord fails to develop properly. It occurs when a developing baby's spinal cord fails to develop or close properly while in the womb. Symptoms can sometimes be seen on the skin above the spinal defect. They include an abnormal tuft of hair, a birthmark or protruding spinal cord tissue. When treatment is necessary, it's carried out through surgery to close the defect. Other treatments focus on managing complications.
